Award.AwardTitle: Spectroscopy and Imaging of Organometallic Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Dong-Sheng Yang of the University of Kentucky is funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A (CSDM-A) Program for a project titled "Spectroscopy and Imaging of Organometallic Complexes." The conversion of hydrocarbons, the major constituents of petroleum and natural gas, into chemical feedstocks is an important commercial process. The design of selective and efficient catalysts (species that facilitate a chemical reaction) is a current area of much interest. This study will look at the way metal atoms interact with hydrocarbons. This information will show how hydrocarbons can be converted into other chemicals and should guide the design of new catalysts that can reduce the energy required for hydrocarbon conversion. The project provides technically challenging training for a diverse group of students at all levels and prepares them for careers in industry, academia, or the public sector.

Ttransient organometallic complexes formed in the reactions of the neutral lanthanide atoms and small hydrocarbons will be characterized by single-photon ZEKE/MATI spectroscopy, PEVMI, and two color IR-UV photoionization. Accurate IEs, metal-ligand and ligand based vibrational frequencies, and structural differences between the neutral and cationic species will be determined. Electronic states and molecular structures will be investigated by comparing the spectra of chemically and electronically similar molecular systems and by combining the spectroscopic measurements with theoretical calculations. The investigator is active in the development of undergraduate curricula and in the mentoring programs for local K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hydrocarbons are the major constituents of petroleum and natural gas. The conversion of hydrocarbons into functionalized chemicals for daily or industrial uses is an important commercial process. Metal catalysis reduces energy consumptions and speeds up the process under mild conditions. This work discovered the way metal atoms interacted with hydrocarbons and showed how hydrocarbons were converted into other chemicals.  The new knowledge from this work shall provide guidance for the design of selective and efficient catalysts. A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself be consumed in the process. The project provided technically challenging training for a diverse group of students at all levels and prepares them for careers in industry, academia, or the public sector.

Results from this project produced numerous publications in professional journals and national or international professional conferences.  Specific scientific outcomes are the accurate ionization energies, metal-ligand and ligand-based vibrational energies, electronic states, molecular structures of short-lived metal-hydrocarbon complexes, and reaction pathways for the formation of the metal intermediates and products. The ionization energy is a basic thermochemical property of a molecule and is used to obtain the metal-ligand bond energy of the uncharged molecule through a thermodynamic relation. The metal-ligand vibrational energies give a direct evidence about the metal-ligand bonding, whereas the ligand-based vibrational frequencies probe the geometry of the metal-activated hydrocarbon fragments. The degree of the charge effect reveals the nature of the electron bonding in the highest molecular orbital. The knowledge about the formation,  bonding, structures, and electronic states of these reactive specie gives new insight into the dynamics and mechanisms of metal-activation reactions with hydrocarbons and provide benchmarks to test new or improved computational modelling on molecular properties.

The project trained young students in technically challenging fields and prepared them effectively in diverse sectors of technology-driven economy. The students have been trained in sophisticated instrumentation, state-of-the-art laser spectroscopy and imaging, and modern computational chemistry. They have been equipped with skills in the design, operation, and interpretation of scientific experiments and in the presentation and communication of research discoveries.
